courses.title: Monarchy in Austria: The Habsburgs
courses.description: The name Habsburg goes back to the village and the castle Habsburg in the Swiss Aargau. Here the Habsburgs had their ancestral seat in the 12th and 13th centuries and carried the family name Habsburg since the year 1108. It took only a few generations for the Habsburg family to significantly expand their territory and secure the German kingship in conjunction with the Roman emperorship. The Habsburgs were one of the most important ruling dynasties in Europe, whose influence extended over centuries. Their rule began in the 13th century and shaped the history of many European countries. The most important events include:

events.title: The Rise of the Habsburgs
events.content: In 1273, Rudolf I of Habsburg was elected King of the Holy Roman Empire. This marked the beginning of Habsburg rule. Rudolf used his power to consolidate the empire and strengthen his position.

events.title: The Division of the Habsburgs
events.content: In 1379, the House of Habsburg was divided into two main lines: the Austrian and the Albertinian lines. This division led to internal conflicts and struggles for supremacy within the family.

events.title: Maximilian I and Habsburg Marriage Policy
events.content: Maximilian I, one of the most famous Habsburgs, used skillful marriages to expand the power and influence of the family. Through his marriage to Mary of Burgundy, he acquired rich territories in the Netherlands.

events.title: Charles V and the Challenge of the Reformation
events.content: Charles V, Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, ruled over a vast empire that stretched from Spain through the Netherlands to Austria. During his reign, he had to deal with the Reformation initiated by Martin Luther.

events.title: The Thirty Years' War and the Peace of Westphalia
events.content: The Thirty Years' War (1618-1648) was a devastating conflict in Central Europe, which had religious, political, and territorial causes. The Peace of Westphalia ended the war and led to significant changes in the political landscape of Europe.

events.title: Maria Theresa and the Reforms
events.content: Maria Theresa, who ruled in the 18th century, carried out extensive reforms in administration, education, and the economy. She modernized the Habsburg Empire and strengthened her position as a ruler.

events.title: The Decline of the Habsburgs
events.content: In the 19th century, the decline of the Habsburgs began. After World War I and the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Monarchy in 1918, Habsburg rule ended definitively.

courses.title: Romeo and Juliet
courses.description: Romeo and Juliet is a tragedy written by William Shakespeare early in his career about two young star-crossed lovers whose deaths ultimately reconcile their feuding families. It was among Shakespeare's most popular plays during his lifetime and, along with Hamlet, is one of his most frequently performed plays. Today, the title characters are regarded as archetypal young lovers. The most important events in the play include:

events.title: The Capulet Ball
events.content: Romeo, a Montague, crashes the Capulet's party where he meets Juliet, and they instantly fall in love, despite the feud between their families.

events.title: The Balcony Scene
events.content: Romeo sneaks into the Capulet orchard and overhears Juliet confessing her love for him. They exchange vows of love and plan to marry in secret.

events.title: The Secret Marriage
events.content: Romeo and Juliet are married secretly by Friar Laurence, who hopes their union will end the feud between the Montagues and the Capulets.

events.title: The Tragic Duel
events.content: Tybalt kills Mercutio, which leads to Romeo avenging his friend's death by killing Tybalt. As a result, Romeo is banished from Verona.

events.title: The Potion Plan
events.content: Juliet and Friar Laurence concoct a plan to reunite her with Romeo. Juliet takes a potion that makes her appear dead, hoping Romeo will come to take her away once she wakes.

events.title: The Final Tragedy
events.content: Romeo, believing Juliet is truly dead, takes his own life. When Juliet awakens and finds Romeo dead beside her, she also takes her own life.

courses.title: The Four Seasons by Vivaldi
courses.description: The Four Seasons is a group of four violin concertos by Italian composer Antonio Vivaldi, each of which gives musical expression to a season of the year. They were composed around 1716-1717 and published in 1725. The most important parts of The Four Seasons include:

events.title: Spring
events.content: The first concerto in the set, Spring, is the best known. It evokes the season with sounds of birds, a murmuring brook, and gentle breezes.

events.title: Summer
events.content: Summer is characterized by slower movements that represent the languid heat and faster passages that depict thunderstorms.

events.title: Autumn
events.content: Autumn evokes the harvest season with festive dance movements and a depiction of a hunt with hunting horns.

events.title: Winter
events.content: Winter features crisp, staccato notes that represent the cold and biting winds of the season.

courses.title: The Nile River
courses.description: The Nile is a major north-flowing river in northeastern Africa, and is commonly regarded as the longest river in the world. It is about 6,650 km (4,130 mi) long and its drainage basin covers eleven countries. The most important aspects of the Nile River include:

events.title: Geography of the Nile
events.content: The Nile flows through northeastern Africa and is typically regarded as the longest river in the world. It runs through eleven countries: Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, South Sudan, Sudan, and Egypt.

events.title: Historical Significance
events.content: The Nile has been the lifeline of civilization in Egypt since the Stone Age. Its waters provided the ancient Egyptians with fertile land, transportation, and materials for building.

events.title: The Nile Delta
events.content: The Nile Delta is one of the world's largest river deltas, stretching from Alexandria in the west to Port Said in the east. It is a rich agricultural region that has been farmed for thousands of years.

events.title: The Aswan High Dam
events.content: The Aswan High Dam, completed in 1970, is one of the largest embankment dams in the world. It created Lake Nasser and has had a significant impact on the economy and agriculture of Egypt.

courses.title: Ancient Greece
courses.description: Ancient Greece is the civilization that emerged on the Greek peninsula and the islands of the Aegean Sea from around the 8th century BC to the end of antiquity (c. AD 600). Known for its rich contributions to art, philosophy, politics, and science, the period is marked by major historical events and figures. The most important aspects of Ancient Greece include:

events.title: The Birth of Democracy
events.content: In the 5th century BC, Athens developed the concept of democracy, where citizens had the right to vote on laws and policies. This was a radical departure from the monarchies and oligarchies that had previously dominated the region.

events.title: The Persian Wars
events.content: The Persian Wars were a series of conflicts between Greece and the Persian Empire in the 5th century BC. Key battles included Marathon, Thermopylae, and Salamis, which highlighted Greek unity and military prowess.

events.title: The Golden Age of Athens
events.content: The period following the Persian Wars saw a cultural and political flowering in Athens. This era produced great works of art, drama, and philosophy, and saw the construction of the Parthenon.

events.title: The Peloponnesian War
events.content: The Peloponnesian War (431-404 BC) was a protracted conflict between Athens and Sparta, along with their respective allies. The war ultimately led to the downfall of Athens and the weakening of Greek states.

events.title: Alexander the Great
events.content: In the 4th century BC, Alexander the Great of Macedon conquered a vast empire that stretched from Greece to Egypt and into northwest India. His conquests spread Greek culture and influence throughout the known world.

events.title: The Hellenistic Period
events.content: Following Alexander's death, his empire fragmented into several Hellenistic kingdoms. This period saw the spread of Greek culture and the blending of Greek and Eastern influences in art, science, and governance.

courses.title: Vincent van Gogh
courses.description: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter who created about 2,100 artworks, including around 860 oil paintings, most of which date from the last two years of his life. Known for his bold, dramatic brush strokes, his work helped lay the foundations of modern art. The most important aspects of Vincent van Gogh's life and work include:

events.title: Early Life and Struggles
events.content: Van Gogh was born in 1853 in the Netherlands. Despite showing early interest in art, he struggled with mental illness and poverty throughout his life.

events.title: Paris and the Impressionists
events.content: In 1886, Van Gogh moved to Paris where he was influenced by the Impressionists and Post-Impressionists, including artists like Monet, Renoir, and Seurat.

events.title: Arles and the Yellow House
events.content: In 1888, Van Gogh moved to Arles in the south of France, where he hoped to start an artist colony. He painted many of his most famous works here, including 'Sunflowers' and 'The Bedroom'.

events.title: Mental Health and Hospitalization
events.content: Van Gogh's mental health deteriorated in Arles, leading to his hospitalization. During this period, he painted 'Starry Night', one of his most famous works.

events.title: Final Years and Legacy
events.content: Van Gogh moved to Auvers-sur-Oise in 1890, where he continued to paint until his death. He died from a gunshot wound, widely believed to be self-inflicted. His work gained significant recognition posthumously, influencing countless artists and movements.

resources.title: Vincent van Gogh - The Complete Works
